pageContext.description:
A Late Bronze Age, cast copper-alloy socketed hammer (c. 1000 - 800 BC), that dating based on Rowland's statement that they are a more defined feature of Late Bronze Age hoards. (Rowlands 1976: 45). It has a sub-rectangular mouth with a narrow collar moulding, the sides of the hammer taper gently from the mouth towards a rectangular working face. There is no evidence of it having any loop. That working face has been well used with the typical side/edge protuberances from that use. There is a thick casting seem running along the length of both narrow sides and the narrow collar is fritted around the edge.



The inner dimensions of the socket at the collar are - 17.3 mm x 15.4 mm with the wall thickness at that point varying from 2.38 mm to approximately 3.6 mm and the base measures 19.97 x 15.9mm The surface has a dark green bronze patina with some corrosion scars to the edges.



A similar type can be found at - IOW-8B13A7 & IOW-A05DE6
